Spinal cord abnormalities and a cutaneous lumbosacral finding would not be seen. $#(Choice D)#  Failure of notochord separation from the underlying endoderm leads to neurenteric cysts (eg, spinal tumors with gastrointestinal epithelium) rather than spinal dysraphism. $#Educational objective# Closed spinal dysraphism (spina bifida occulta or closed neural tube defect) often presents with cutaneous lumbosacral findings (eg, deep pit, hemangioma, tuft of hair) in the newborn period.  Pathogenesis involves failure of vertebral arch fusion, and imaging may suggest an underlying tethered cord (eg, low-lying conus medullaris, thickened filum terminale).

title: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit.  Her first child was born with a hydrocele and syndactyly of the first and second toes.  The patient has no significant medical conditions and takes no medications except for a multivitamin.  Examination shows clear lungs and normal S1 and S2 heart sounds.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Uterine size, fetal movements, and fetal cardiac activity are all within normal limits.  The patient undergoes an amniocentesis at 18 weeks gestation.  Amniotic fluid analysis shows an increased level of acetylcholinesterase.  This patient's amniocentesis results most likely suggest failure of which of the following processes?
answer_1: A. Epithelial cell apoptosis in the embryonic duodenum
answer_2: B. Fusion of the edges of the neural plate
answer_3: C. Involution of the thyroglossal duct
answer_5: E. Migration of neural crest cells
answer_6: F. Obliteration of the processus vaginalis
right_answer: B. Fusion of the edges of the neural plate
explanation_2: $Patients at increased risk for congenital defects (eg, maternal age ≥35) may be offered @amniocentesis@ for prenatal diagnosis.  Amniotic fluid consists primarily of fetal urine; therefore, it can contain fetal serum proteins such as alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).  Amniotic fluid does not usually contain #acetylcholinesterase# (AChE), an enzyme normally concentrated in the #cerebrospinal fluid# (CSF).  Therefore, #elevated AChE# on amniocentesis suggests a leak of fetal CSF into the amniotic cavity known as an #open neural tube defect# (NTD). $NTDs occur due to #failed fusion of the neural plate edges# during the fourth week of fetal development.  Fusion begins in the cervical region and proceeds toward the cranial and caudal ends of the neural tube (ie, rostral and caudal neuropores).  Failed rostral neuropore closure causes anencephaly, and failed caudal neuropore closure causes @spina bifida@.  A persistent opening between the neural tube and the amniotic cavity allows leakage of AFP and AChE into the amniotic fluid.  AFP can also cross the placenta and become elevated in the maternal serum. $#(Choice A)#  Duodenal atresia results from impaired recanalization of the duodenum due to failure of epithelial cell apoptosis.  It causes elevated amniotic fluid volume but not elevated AChE on amniocentesis.  The syndactyly of the patient's first child is also an example of failed apoptosis of mesenchyme between the digits. $#(Choices C, E, and F)#  Failed involution of the thyroglossal tract can cause a persistent thyroglossal duct cyst.  @Hirschsprung disease@ involves failed neural crest cell migration into the sigmoid colon/rectum.  Failure of the processus vaginalis to obliterate can lead to congenital hydrocele or @indirect inguinal hernia@.  None of these conditions are associated with increased AChE in the amniotic fluid because they do not involve a persistent opening between the fetal neural tube and the amniotic cavity. $#(Choice D)#  Advanced maternal age is a risk factor for Down syndrome (meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21), which presents with low AFP and normal AChE levels in the amniotic fluid. $#Educational objective# Neural tube defects (NTDs) most often occur when the neural folds fail to fuse in the region of the anterior or posterior neuropores.  An open NTD allows leakage of alpha-fetoprotein and acetylcholinesterase into the amniotic fluid, leading to elevated levels detected on amniocentesis.

title: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, comes to the office for prenatal evaluation.  The patient says she had been using condoms for birth control and unintentionally became pregnant.  Her last menstrual period was 2 months ago, and home pregnancy tests are positive.  She has not been taking prenatal vitamins.  The patient has a healthy, 5-year-old daughter who was born after an uneventful pregnancy.  She has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, and her joint symptoms are controlled with methotrexate therapy.  The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no other medications.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Serum β-hCG is elevated, and transvaginal ultrasonography shows a normal gestational sac and embryo.  This patient's unborn child is at the greatest risk for which of the following congenital defects?
table_3: §^#Folate antagonists#∆⨉∆⨉ §^#Mechanism# ∆^#Drug# ∆^#Therapeutic applications# §^#Inhibition of DHFR# ∆^Methotrexate ∆ • Rheumatoid arthritis • Cancer §↕ ∆^Sulfasalazine ∆ • Rheumatoid arthritis • Inflammatory bowel disease §↕ ∆^Triamterene ∆ • Diuretic (with HCTZ) for edema & hypertension §↕ ∆^Trimethoprim ∆ • Cystitis • Pneumocystis pneumonia (with sulfamethoxazole) §^#Variable inhibition of folate metabolism# ∆ • Valproic acid • Carbamazepine • Phenytoin ∆ • Seizure disorders • Bipolar disorder (valproic acid & carbamazepine) %#DHFR# = dihydrofolate reductase; #HCTZ# = hydrochlorothiazide.
explanation_2: This patient with an unintended pregnancy has been taking #methotrexate#, a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug, to control symptoms of #rheumatoid arthritis#.  Methotrexate is a folic acid analog that #competitively inhibits# @dihydrofolate reductase@, which produces nucleic acid precursors that are essential to DNA synthesis and repair.  #Rapidly dividing cells# (eg, neural tube cells, stem cells, hepatic cells, epithelial cells) are #particularly susceptible# to folate antagonism.  All patients taking methotrexate should also take a daily folic acid supplement to ameliorate the potential adverse effects (eg, oral ulcers, hepatotoxicity). $Methotrexate and other folate antagonists have #abortifacient# and/or #teratogenic# effects when used during the first trimester.  They are contraindicated in pregnant women except under specific circumstances (eg, cancer therapy with no better alternative, treatment of ectopic pregnancy).  Adverse effects of methotrexate use to the fetus include cardiovascular, urinary tract, and #neural tube defects# (eg, anencephaly, spina bifida). $#(Choice A)#  Under the influence of Hox (homeobox) genes, the branchial arches develop into many head and neck tissues (eg, muscles, bones, and cartilage of the face, neck, and pharynx).  Retinoids (eg, topical tretinoin) are vitamin A derivatives used in the treatment of acne that interfere with the Hox signaling pathways.  If used during pregnancy, they can cause branchial arch abnormalities (eg, CNS, thymic, and craniofacial defects). $#(Choice C)#  Renal dysplasia can be a complication of second or third trimester fetal exposure to ACE inhibitors in hypertensive mothers.  Because fetal renal function is essential to maintain amniotic fluid volume, impaired renal function can lead to pulmonary hypoplasia, limb contractions, growth restriction, or cord compression with poor fetal outcomes. $#(Choice D)#  Sacral agenesis (ie, caudal regression syndrome) is a rare malformation that occurs almost exclusively in infants of diabetic mothers.  Defects can include incomplete development of the sacrum, lumbar vertebrae, and lower extremities. $#(Choice E)#  Skeletal lesions can occur in congenital syphilis infection due to an inflammatory response (eg, periostitis, osteochondritis) to Treponema pallidum spirochetes in highly vascular areas of bones (eg, @Hutchinson teeth@).  Although methotrexate exposure can cause skeletal development abnormalities, discrete inflammatory lesions would not be expected. $#(Choice F)#  Thyroid hypoplasia is a complication of inadvertent fetal exposure to radioactive iodine (I131) in patients receiving treatment for hyperthyroidism or thyroid cancer who unintentionally become pregnant. $#Educational objective# Methotrexate and other folic acid antagonists adversely affect rapidly dividing cells (eg, epithelial cells, stem cells, neural tube cells) by limiting the production of precursors essential to DNA synthesis and repair.  If used in the first trimester of pregnancy, these drugs can cause major congenital abnormalities (eg, cardiovascular abnormalities, neural tube defects).

title: A newborn is taken to the neonatal intensive care unit after delivery due to respiratory distress.  The neonate was born full-term, and there were no significant complications during pregnancy or delivery.  Once the patient is stabilized, a detailed physical examination is performed and shows an underdeveloped mandible and hypoplastic zygomatic bones.  Genetic testing confirms a gene mutation that results in abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal arches.  Which of the following structures is also likely abnormal in this patient?
explanation_2: The developing embryo has #6 pharyngeal arches#, and all but the fifth arch contribute to adult structures.  The mesoderm forms muscular and vascular elements, and neural crest cells form bony and cartilaginous structures.  Each arch is also innervated by a specific @cranial nerve (CN)@. $• The #first arch# is associated with the trigeminal nerve (CN V).  Its bony derivatives include the maxilla, #zygoma#, #mandible#, incus, and malleus, and its muscular derivatives include the muscles of mastication (eg, masseter, temporalis). $• The #second arch# is associated with the facial nerve (CN VII) and gives rise to the styloid process of the temporal bone, lesser horn of the hyoid, and #stapes#.  Muscular derivatives include the muscles of facial expression. $This patient's presentation is consistent with Treacher Collins syndrome, a rare genetic disorder resulting in the abnormal development of the first and second pharyngeal arches.  The associated craniofacial abnormalities (eg, mandibular, maxillary, and zygomatic bone hypoplasia) often result in airway compromise, while absent or abnormal ossicles (eg, incus, malleus, stapes) can lead to profound conductive hearing loss. $#(Choices A, E, and F)#  The fourth and sixth arches make up the cartilaginous structures of the larynx, including the cricoid and thyroid cartilages.  Derivatives of these arches (eg, most pharyngeal and laryngeal muscles) are innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X). $#(Choice B)#  The third pharyngeal arch is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).  Neurologic dysfunction may lead to impaired taste perception and an absent gag reflex. $#(Choice C)#  Although the lesser horn of the hyoid bone is derived from the secondary pharyngeal arch, the greater horn of the hyoid is derived from the third arch. $#Educational objective# Disrupted development of the first and second pharyngeal arches results in hypoplasia of the arches' musculoskeletal derivatives, including the mandible, maxilla, zygomatic bones, and ossicles.

title: A 38-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to severe abdominal pain and delivers a stillborn neonate who is missing a large portion of the scalp and skull, partially exposing the brain, which is also only partially formed.  The patient did not know she was pregnant and had no prenatal care.  Medical history is significant for bipolar disorder and chronic hypertension.  Interview of the patient reveals pressured and tangential speech, and she states that she takes certain prescription medications when she remembers but cannot identify which ones.  If used during pregnancy, which of the following substances most likely contributed to this neonate's abnormalities?
explanation_2: $This stillborn neonate has #anencephaly#, or absence of the forebrain and major portions of the skull.  Anencephaly is an #open neural tube defect# (NTD) caused by #defective primary neurulation#, an embryologic process in which the neural folds fuse in the midline to create the neural tube.  Fusion starts in the cervical region and extends rostrally and caudally to the anterior and posterior neuropores, respectively.  Failure of anterior (rostral) neuropore closure results in @anencephaly@, whereas failure of posterior (caudal) neuropore closure results in an @open spinal dysraphism@ (eg, myelomeningocele). $Most isolated NTDs are related to folate (vitamin B9) deficiency (eg, poor dietary intake).  Folate supplementation is recommended for all women of childbearing age because the neural tube develops during the time when most women are unaware of their pregnancy. $In addition to #insufficient dietary folate#, first trimester use of #medications that impair folate metabolism# are associated with a 10- to 20-fold increased risk of NTDs.  These medications include #valproate#, which is typically prescribed for bipolar disorder (likely in this patient) or epilepsy.  Others include methotrexate and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.  These medications are contraindicated in pregnancy. $#(Choices A, D, and E)#  ACE inhibitors, isotretinoin, and lithium are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic effects.  ACE inhibitors cause fetal renal damage, lithium use is associated with increased incidence of @Ebstein anomaly@, and isotretinoin is a potent teratogen that can cause a multitude of defects (eg, microcephaly, ear/facial deformities, cardiac defects).  However, use of these substances during pregnancy is not associated with NTDs. $#(Choices B and C)#  Alcohol use is associated with @fetal alcohol syndrome@; findings include a smooth filtrum, thin upper lip, and small palpebral fissures.  Heroin or other opiate use during pregnancy can lead to withdrawal in the infant postnatally (neonatal abstinence syndrome).  NTDs are not associated with prenatal alcohol or opiate use. $#Educational objective# Failure of neural tube closure results in neural tube defects (eg, anencephaly, meningomyelocele).  Folate deficiency is the greatest risk factor, and medications that impair folate metabolism (eg, valproate) are associated with an increased risk.

title: A newborn boy is being evaluated in the nursery.  The patient was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery.  A cystic lesion is noted overlying the lumbosacral spine region.  The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Ultrasound imaging confirms a neural tube defect.  The mother had no prenatal care, and further discussion reveals that she took a medication known to be teratogenic during pregnancy.  Exposure to the medication most likely occurred during which of the following weeks of embryonic development?
answer_1: A. The week prior to fertilization
explanation_2: $This patient has a @neural tube defect@.  Like other major congenital anomalies, neural tube defects develop during the embryonic stage of fetal development, or #3-8 weeks# after fertilization (ie, weeks 5-10 of gestation).  During this crucial time, the embryo is undergoing #organogenesis#, or rapid cell division and differentiation of all major organ systems, making it particularly #susceptible to teratogens#. $The beginning of the embryonic stage is marked by @gastrulation@, which establishes 3 distinct cell layers: ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.  All tissues and organs are derived from these 3 layers.  Structures formed by the end of the embryonic stage include the gastrointestinal tract and lungs (endoderm); the heart, kidneys, and spleen (mesoderm); and the skin and central nervous system (ectoderm). $The central nervous system develops via @neurulation@ during the #third and fourth weeks#.  During neurulation, the neural plate forms from the ectoderm, and the lateral edges of the plate (neural folds) migrate toward the midline and fuse.  Fusion begins in the cervical region and extends rostrally and caudally, forming the neural tube (precursor to the brain and spinal cord).  The ends, or neuropores, close at the end of the fourth week.  In this case, exposure to a teratogenic medication (eg, folic acid antagonist such as valproic acid) likely occurred during #neurulation#, interfering with caudal neural tube closure and causing a #neural tube defect#. $#(Choices A and B)#  Fertilization is the process by which the male and female gametes form a zygote.  The zygote transforms into a blastocyst, which implants in the uterine wall approximately 1 week after fertilization.  Significant teratogenic exposure prior to gastrulation usually results in spontaneous abortion or no abnormalities, as the undamaged pluripotent cells can fully compensate if enough survive. $#(Choices D and E)#  The central nervous system matures throughout pregnancy and can be affected by teratogens beyond the first 8 weeks (eg, alcohol causing fetal alcohol syndrome).  However, defects related to neural tube formation (neurulation) occur only during the early embryonic period. $#Educational objective# Organogenesis occurs in the embryonic stage of development (3-8 weeks after fertilization), during which time the embryo is particularly susceptible to teratogens.  Neurulation (neural tube formation) occurs during weeks 3 and 4, and abnormalities in this process result in neural tube defects.

title: A 38-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision.  She sustained no injuries in the collision but is adamant she did not see the car that hit her along the front side of her vehicle.  The patient also reports that she has been having daily headaches and has not menstruated in the last 4 months.  On physical examination, there is bitemporal hemianopia but no other abnormalities.  MRI of the brain is shown below.
title_2: This patient's lesion most likely originates from which of the following embryologic layers?
table_3: §^#Embryologic derivatives#∆⨉∆⨉ §Ectoderm ∆^Surface ectoderm ∆ • Anterior pituitary (Rathke pouch) • Lens & cornea • Inner ear sensory organs, olfactory epithelium • Nasal & oral epithelial linings, salivary glands • Epidermis, sweat & mammary glands §↕ ∆^Neural tube ∆ • Brain & spinal cord • Posterior pituitary, pineal gland • Retina §↕ ∆^Neural crest ∆ • Neural ganglia, adrenal medulla • Schwann cells; pia & arachnoid mater • Aorticopulmonary septum & endocardial cushions • Branchial arches (bones & cartilage) • Skull bones • Melanocytes §^Mesoderm ∆⨉ ∆ • Muscles (skeletal, cardiac & smooth) • Connective tissue, bone & cartilage • Serosal linings (eg, peritoneum) • Cardiovascular & lymphatic system • Spleen & hemopoietic cells • Kidney & ureters, internal genitalia • Adrenal cortex §^Endoderm ∆⨉ ∆ • Gastrointestinal tract, liver, pancreas • Lungs • Thymus, parathyroids, thyroid follicular cells • Middle ear epithelium • Bladder & urethra • Parafollicular (C) cells* %*Formerly thought to be of neural crest origin.
explanation_2: This patient with @pituitary enlargement@ on brain imaging and @bitemporal hemianopia@ (ie, temporal visual field loss due to compression of the optic chiasm) most likely has a #pituitary adenoma#.  These benign tumors arise from the #anterior pituitary# and are the most common cause of sellar masses in adults.  Secondary hypogonadism (eg, #amenorrhea#) frequently occurs in patients with pituitary tumors, and can be caused by excessive prolactin secretion (which suppresses hypothalamic secretion of GnRH) or direct compression of gonadotrope cells by the expanding mass. $All tissues are derivatives of the 3 primary germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, endoderm) that form during @gastrulation@.  As epiblast cells migrate downward through the primitive streak to form the mesoderm and endoderm layers, a portion of them also migrate cranially through the primitive node (the cephalic end of the primitive streak) to form a midline, mesoderm-derived cellular cord known as the @notochord@.  The notochord induces the overlying ectoderm to differentiate into the neuroectoderm and form the neural plate, which gives rise to the neural crest and neural tube #(choices C and D)#; the remainder of the ectoderm becomes the #surface ectoderm#. $The anterior pituitary is derived from the #Rathke pouch#, an evagination of the @surface ectoderm@ that lines the fetal oral cavity #(choices A and B)#.  In contrast, the posterior pituitary (pars nervosa and pituitary stalk) is derived from the infundibulum, an extension of neuroectoderm from the diencephalon; posterior pituitary tumors are rare. $#(Choice E)#  The notochord becomes the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral discs in adults $#Educational objective# Pituitary adenoma is a benign tumor arising from the anterior pituitary and the most common cause of sellar masses (headache, bitemporal hemianopia, hypogonadism) in adults.  The anterior pituitary forms from the surface ectoderm, one of the 3 tissues derived from the ectoderm (ie, surface ectoderm, neural tube, neural crest).

title: A 22-year-old man comes to the office due to occasional dull headaches that awaken him from sleep.  The patient has no associated neurologic deficits.  There is no history of migraines in the family.  His temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 12/min.  On physical examination, there are several 3- to 5-cm flat, pigmented spots on his trunk.  There are also multiple, subcentimeter, soft, fleshy, cutaneous tumors located on his trunk and neck.  The predominant cells forming these tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
table_3: §^#Embryologic derivatives#∆⨉∆⨉ §Ectoderm ∆^Surface ectoderm ∆ • Anterior pituitary (Rathke pouch) • Lens & cornea • Inner ear sensory organs, olfactory epithelium • Nasal & oral epithelial linings, salivary glands • Epidermis, sweat & mammary glands §↕ ∆^Neural tube ∆ • Brain & spinal cord • Posterior pituitary, pineal gland • Retina §↕ ∆^Neural crest ∆ • Neural ganglia, adrenal medulla • Schwann cells; pia & arachnoid mater • Aorticopulmonary septum & endocardial cushions • Branchial arches (bones & cartilage) • Skull bones • Melanocytes §^Mesoderm ∆⨉ ∆ • Muscles (skeletal, cardiac & smooth) • Connective tissue, bone & cartilage • Serosal linings (eg, peritoneum) • Cardiovascular & lymphatic system • Spleen & hemopoietic cells • Kidney & ureters, internal genitalia • Adrenal cortex §^Endoderm ∆⨉ ∆ • Gastrointestinal tract, liver, pancreas • Lungs • Thymus, parathyroids, thyroid follicular cells • Middle ear epithelium • Bladder & urethra • Parafollicular (C) cells* %*Formerly thought to be of neural crest origin.
explanation_2: This patient has clinical features of #neurofibromatosis type I# (von Recklinghausen disease), an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene.  Patients typically develop hyperpigmented macules (@Café-au-lait spots@) over the trunk soon after birth and are at increased risk of developing central nervous system neoplasms (eg, optic gliomas, pilocytic astrocytomas), which can cause elevated intracranial pressure and headache. $#Cutaneous neurofibromas# usually manifest during early adolescence as multiple, raised, fleshy tumors (<2 cm) that often increase in size and number with age.  These are benign nerve sheath neoplasms predominantly comprised of #Schwann cells#, which are embryologically derived from the #neural crest#. $#(Choice A)#  The endoderm gives rise to thyroid follicular cells (derived from the primitive tongue) and the epithelial linings of the gastrointestinal tract, middle ear, lungs, bladder, and most of the urethra.  It also gives rise to the bulk of the liver and pancreas, as these structures form from outpouchings of the primitive gut tube. $#(Choice B)#  The mesoderm is divided into paraxial, intermediate, and lateral sections and gives rise to muscles, bones, blood, connective tissue, dermis, and the kidneys/ureters. $#(Choice D)#  The neural tube gives rise to neurons of the central nervous system and the neurohypophysis, retina, pineal gland, preganglionic autonomic fibers, astrocytes, and ependymal cells. $#(Choice E)#  The notochord almost completely regresses in humans, and its only major derivative is the nucleus pulposus of the intervertebral disc.  Vertebrae are derived from the paraxial mesoderm. $#(Choice F)#  The surface ectoderm gives rise to the epidermis, lens of the eye, outer layer of the cornea, nasal and oral epithelium, and anal epithelium below the dentate line. $#Educational objective# Neurofibromatosis type I (von Recklinghausen disease) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene.  Patients characteristically develop numerous cutaneous neurofibromas comprised mostly of Schwann cells, which are embryologically derived from the neural crest.

title: Researchers working at a national foundation for prematurity and birth defects are investigating the physiologic processes that occur during embryonic kidney development.  Their research focuses on the inductive signals exchanged between the metanephric diverticulum and metanephric blastema that drive their differentiation into tissues forming the mature kidney.  The researchers develop a method to reproduce the inductive signal that normally comes from the metanephric diverticulum.  After applying this inductive signal to the metanephric blastema, which of the following adult derivatives will most likely develop?
explanation_2: $Embryonic kidney development begins with the formation of the nephrogenic cord (derived from the urogenital ridge, or intermediate mesoderm).  The cord sequentially forms 3 sets of nephric systems: pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros. $The rudimentary pronephros forms first and later completely regresses.  The #mesonephros# forms next from the midportion of the nephrogenic cord; in females, it regresses, whereas in males it persists as the #wolffian ducts#, forming the ductus deferens and epididymis. $The #metanephros# forms last from the caudal end of the nephrogenic cord and persists as the #mature upper urinary tract#.  Development of the metanephros begins with formation of the metanephric diverticulum (ureteric bud), which penetrates the sacral intermediate mesoderm to induce the formation of the metanephric blastema.  The reciprocal exchange of #inductive signals# between the ureteric bud and metanephric blastema drives their differentiation into the structures that form the upper urinary tract. $• #Metanephric blastema#:  This structure gives rise to the glomeruli, Bowman space, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and #distal convoluted tubules#. $• Metanephric diverticulum (ureteric bud):  This structure gives rise to the collecting system of the kidney, including the collecting tubules and ducts, major and minor calyces, renal pelvis, and ureters #(choices A, C, D, and E)#. $#Educational objective# The mature upper urinary tract is derived from the metanephros, which comprises the metanephric blastema and metanephric diverticulum (ureteric bud).  The metanephric blastema gives rise to the glomeruli, Bowman space, proximal tubules, loop of Henle, and distal convoluted tubules.  The ureteric bud becomes the collecting system of the kidney (eg, collecting tubules and ducts, major and minor calyces, renal pelvis, ureters).

title: A 1-hour-old boy is in the neonatal intensive care unit due to tachypnea and hypoxia.  The infant was born at 39 weeks gestation via cesarean delivery due to recurrent variable decelerations.  The pregnancy was complicated by lack of prenatal care.  The infant weighs 3.2 kg (7 lb 1 oz).  Physical examination shows a flattened nose and bilateral club feet.  Breath sounds are markedly diminished bilaterally.  The infant is intubated and mechanically ventilated, but oxygen levels do not improve.  He dies an hour later.  Which of the following is most likely to be found during autopsy of this infant?
explanation_2: $This infant likely had #Potter sequence#, which is characterized by pulmonary hypoplasia, flat facies, and lower limb deformity (eg, club foot).  Potter sequence is caused by a #urinary tract anomaly# that leads to #decreased fetal urine output#.  It is classically associated with bilateral renal agenesis but can occur secondary to other etiologies, including @posterior urethral valves@ or fetal exposure to @ACE inhibitors@. $Because fetal urine is the main component of amniotic fluid, decreased fetal urine output can lead to low or absent amniotic fluid levels (ie, #severe oligohydramnios#).  Inadequate amniotic fluid levels allow for #increased external compression# of the fetal face (#flat facies#) and extremities (eg, #club foot#).  In addition, the umbilical cord is often compressed such that fetal heart rate abnormalities (eg, recurrent decelerations) are common during labor. $Amniotic fluid also provides the fluid and growth factors needed for fetal lung development.  Therefore, neonates with Potter sequence have #pulmonary hypoplasia# due to the lack of normal alveolar distension by aspirated amniotic fluid.  Both lungs are affected, and #respiratory failure# (ie, hypoxia) is the most common cause of death in affected infants. $#(Choice A)#  Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can cause neonatal hypoxia due to lung compression by the herniated abdominal contents; however, infants typically have unilateral (not bilateral) absent breath sounds.  In addition, there is no association with flat facies or limb deformity. $#(Choices B and E)#  Infants with gastrointestinal obstruction proximal to the small bowel (eg, duodenal atresia, @tracheoesophageal fistula@) may have respiratory distress due to stomach distension and subsequent lung compression.  However, these neonates have impaired amniotic fluid swallowing in utero, leading to polyhydramnios. $#(Choice D)#  Surfactant decreases alveolar surface tension, and surfactant deficiency (most commonly associated with prematurity) can cause alveolar collapse and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.  However, surfactant deficiency is not typically associated with flat facies or limb deformity. $#Educational objective# Potter sequence results from a urinary tract anomaly (eg, bilateral renal agenesis) that causes decreased fetal urine output and severe oligohydramnios.  The lack of amniotic fluid causes increased fetal compression (eg, flat facies, limb deformity) and pulmonary hypoplasia (eg, neonatal hypoxia), which is the most common cause of death in affected neonates.

title: A 30-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to recurrent urinary tract infections.  She also has a history of nephrolithiasis.  Vital signs are normal, and examination is unremarkable.  CT scan of the abdomen is shown below.
title_2: Fusion of which of the following embryologic structures most likely explains this patient's CT scan findings?
explanation_2: $This patient's CT scan shows fusion of the right and left renal parenchyma, or #horseshoe kidney#, a congenital anomaly caused by fusion of the #metanephros# in utero. $The @metanephros@ is an embryologic structure that comprises the metanephric blastema, which gives rise to the renal parenchyma, and the ureteric bud, which gives rise to the renal collecting system and ureters.  Abnormal migration of the right and left metanephric blastema can lead to #fusion# of this developing renal parenchyma #along the inferior poles#, forming a U or horseshoe shape.  The fused kidneys begin their physiologic ascent from the pelvis into the abdomen until the isthmus (central fused portion) is physically restricted by the overlying @inferior mesenteric artery@ at its origin from the aorta.  As a result, compared to normal, horseshoe kidneys lie lower in the abdomen.  The isthmus also displaces the renal pelvises superiorly, often causing the ureters to insert abnormally high and pass over the anterior portions of the kidneys or the isthmus. $Although horseshoe kidney is often an incidental or asymptomatic finding, patients are prone to intermittent ureteropelvic junction obstruction and urinary stasis due to the #abnormal orientation# of the kidneys and location of ureteral insertion.  These consequences increase the risk for #nephrolithiasis# as well as retrograde urine flow (ie, reflux) and, therefore, #recurrent urinary tract infections#. $#(Choices A, B, and D)#  The pronephros is a rudimentary nephric system that degenerates in early gestation.  Similarly, much of the rudimentary mesonephros degenerates, although a portion (the mesonephric duct) persists as the ureteric bud.  This patient has horseshoe kidney, a congenital defect involving the renal parenchyma, which is derived only from the metanephric blastema, a component of the metanephros. $#(Choice E)#  Although the nephric systems (including pronephros, mesonephros, and metanephros) are all derived from the urogenital ridge, this structure also gives rise to the gonads, reproductive tract, and adrenal cortex in addition to the kidney.  Horseshoe kidney is due to fusion of the metanephros alone. $#Educational objective# Horseshoe kidney is a congenital anomaly in which fusion of the metanephros (specifically, metanephric blastema) results in fused renal parenchyma along the inferior poles.  Most patients are asymptomatic, but some may develop recurrent urinary tract infections or nephrolithiasis due to abnormal urine flow through the malpositioned kidney and ureters.

title: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine prenatal ultrasound examination.  She is 19 weeks pregnant based on her last menstrual period.  This is the patient's third pregnancy, and there have been no complications.  Family medical history is unremarkable, and both of the patient's children are healthy.  The examination reveals a male fetus with bilaterally enlarged kidneys with diffuse small cysts.  The amniotic fluid volume is very low.  No other anomalies are seen.  Which of the following will most likely be present in the newborn at delivery?
explanation_2: $This mother has oligohydramnios, and the fetus has bilaterally enlarged cystic kidneys.  Because amniotic fluid is largely composed of fetal urine, these findings are concerning for fetal kidney dysfunction and reduced urine production.  In this case, the fetus likely has #autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease# (ARPKD), a condition caused by a mutation in fibrocystin (protein found in epithelial cells of renal tubules).  Fibrocystin deficiency leads to diffuse microcysts, as seen here, and impaired kidney function. $Any condition that causes #anuria or oliguria in utero# (eg, ARPKD, bilateral renal agenesis) results in #severe oligohydramnios# and risk of Potter sequence.  #Potter sequence# is a predictable series of anomalies caused by fetal compression from insufficient amniotic fluid.  Findings include the following: $• #Flattened facies:#  Extrinsic fetal compression leads to a flattened, depressed nasal bridge; prominent epicanthal folds; low-set ears; and a recessed chin. $• #Limb deformities:#  Restricted fetal movement causes deformities such as contractures, hip dislocation, and clubfoot. $• #Pulmonary hypoplasia:#  Restricted thoracic expansion limits fetal lung development, causing respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds after birth.  Amniotic fluid is also thought to promote production of elastin, collagen, and vascular endothelial growth factor in fetal lungs, and oligohydramnios likely results in reduced alveolarization and angiogenesis. $Potter sequence is often fatal in infancy, and patients who survive typically develop chronic lung and kidney disease. $#(Choice A)#  Bladder outlet obstruction (eg, posterior urethral valves) causes bladder distension, bilateral hydronephrosis, and in severe cases impaired kidney function and oligohydramnios.  However, in contrast to this case, renal cysts would not be present. $#(Choice B)#  Cerebral aneurysms are a common complication of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease.  However, most patients remain asymptomatic until adulthood; ARPKD is much more likely in this neonate with severe renal impairment. $#(Choice C)#  Segmental facial hemangiomas may be associated with other anomalies, as in the PHACE syndrome (abnormalities of the #P#osterior fossa; #H#emangiomas; and #A#rterial cerebrovascular, #C#ardiac, and #E#ye anomalies).  Vascular tumors are not associated with ARPKD or Potter sequence. $#(Choice D)#  Intestinal atresia is associated with excessive, not reduced, amniotic fluid (polyhydramnios) due to impaired fluid absorption by the fetal gastrointestinal tract.  Furthermore, this patient's renal findings would not be expected in a patient with intestinal atresia. $#Educational objective# Amniotic fluid is largely composed of fetal urine, and oligohydramnios (low fluid) is often associated with kidney dysfunction in the fetus (eg, diffuse cysts seen in autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease).  Extrinsic fetal compression from a low amniotic fluid level leads to Potter sequence with characteristic findings of flattened facies, limb deformities, and pulmonary hypoplasia.

title: A newborn boy is being evaluated in the delivery room due to respiratory distress.  He was born at 37 weeks gestation to a 28-year-old primigravida via cesarean delivery due to breech presentation.  The mother had limited prenatal care but was noted to have oligohydramnios during pregnancy.  Examination of the infant is significant for a flattened nose and ears, recessed chin, and bilateral clubfoot deformity.  Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally.  This pattern of findings is best classified as which of the following?
table_3: §^#Patterns of congenital anomalies#∆⨉∆⨉ §^#Term# ∆^#Definition# ∆^#Examples# §^#Association# ∆ • ≥2 anomalies that occur together more frequently than expected by chance alone • No known cause ∆ • VACTERL association §^#Syndrome# ∆ • Aggregate of anomalies that develop independently from one another • Caused by an underlying defect (eg, chromosomal abnormality, single gene defect, teratogen) ∆ • Turner syndrome • Marfan syndrome • Fetal alcohol syndrome §^#Sequence# ∆ • Predictable series of anatomically related anomalies • Caused by an inciting event/primary anomaly that subsequently affects development of other structures ∆ • Potter sequence • Pierre Robin sequence %#VACTERL# = #V#ertebral anomaly, #A#norectal malformation, #C#ardiovascular anomaly, #T#racheoesophageal fistula, #E#sophageal atresia, #R#enal &/or radial anomaly, #L#imb defect.
explanation_2: A #sequence# is a predictable series of #anatomically related anomalies# that develop as a consequence of a known primary disturbance (ie, #cause-and-effect# relationship).  In this case, the neonate has @Potter sequence@, a cascade of deformations due to severe #oligohydramnios#. $Low amniotic fluid is typically the result of a genitourinary tract anomaly (eg, bilateral renal agenesis) leading to impaired fetal urine production or preterm prelabor rupture of membranes.  Regardless of the cause, insufficient amniotic fluid causes #fetal constraint and compression#, and this abnormal mechanical force underlies the related anatomic defects of Potter sequence.  Postnatal features include the following: $• #Pulmonary hypoplasia:#  Restricted fetal thoracic expansion leads to alveolar collapse and impaired lung development.  This is the most severe consequence of Potter sequence, manifesting as respiratory distress or decreased breath sounds; it is often fatal. $• #Flattened facies:#  Extrinsic compression leads to the characteristic facial appearance of a flattened nasal bridge, low-set ears, and a recessed chin. $• #Skeletal anomalies:#  Limited fetal movement leads to limb abnormalities such as contractures and clubfoot, as seen in this case. $Potter sequence has been inaccurately referred to as Potter syndrome.  A syndrome is an aggregate of anomalies with a known underlying cause, usually genetic, such as Down syndrome.  However, in a syndrome, the anomalies develop independently from one another rather than sequentially due to causal interaction. $#(Choice A)#  An association is 2 or more anomalies that occur together more often than would be expected by chance alone but without a known cause.  An example is VACTERL association (#V#ertebral anomaly, #A#norectal malformation, #C#ardiovascular anomaly, #T#racheoesophageal fistula, #E#sophageal atresia, #R#enal and/or radial anomaly, #L#imb defect). $#(Choice B)#  Dysplasia refers to the abnormal growth or development of a cell, tissue, or organ (eg, congenital hip dysplasia). $#(Choice C)#  Mosaicism is the occurrence of 2 or more genetically distinct cells within the same patient (eg, mosaic Down syndrome). $#(Choice D)#  Polymorphism refers to genetically distinct normal phenotypes within a population (eg, eye color). $#Educational objective# A sequence is a predictable series of anatomically related anomalies that develop as a consequence of a known primary anomaly (ie, cause-and-effect relationship).  Oligohydramnios leads to fetal compression and the predictable cascade of findings in Potter sequence (eg, pulmonary hypoplasia, facial and limb anomalies).

title: A 34-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal examination.  The patient's pregnancy has been uncomplicated.  She takes a prenatal vitamin daily, and her laboratory results have been normal to date.  The patient's personal and family medical histories are unremarkable.  During the visit, a detailed fetal ultrasound examination reveals severe unilateral hydronephrosis; there is no ureteral dilation.  Male external genitalia are also visible.  If the fetal hydronephrosis is caused by obstruction, which of the following is the most likely site?
explanation_2: $#Fetal hydronephrosis# is a common finding on routine ultrasound examination during the second trimester.  The finding is most commonly #unilateral#, mild, and transient, likely related to a temporary narrowing in the #ureteropelvic junction# (UPJ) during normal development, as the fetal renal pelvis is highly compliant and susceptible to dilation.  In this case, however, the dilation is severe, making a pathologic cause more likely. $The most common pathologic cause of antenatal hydronephrosis is persistent UPJ #obstruction# due to an embryologic defect that develops as follows: $• The fetal @genitourinary tract@ is derived from the metanephric blastema and the ureteric bud (a dorsal outgrowth of the mesonephric duct).  The metanephric blastema develops into functional renal parenchyma by 10 weeks gestation while the ureteric bud develops into the renal pelvis and ureters through sequential dilation and canalization.  The UPJ is the last segment of the fetal ureter to canalize. $• The pathogenesis of fetal UPJ obstruction likely involves #canalization failure# resulting in stenosis of the proximal ureter.  Most cases are unilateral and cause hydronephrosis with calyceal/renal pelvic dilation and without ureteral dilation.  If the condition is not diagnosed prenatally, it may present with a palpable abdominal mass (enlarged kidney) on examination. $#(Choice A)#  Neurogenic causes of obstructive uropathy (eg, spinal cord damage) result in bilateral hydronephrosis along with hydroureter due to dysfunctional voiding. $#(Choices C and D)#  Obstruction of the urethra or urinary meatus causes bilateral, not unilateral, hydronephrosis in addition to ureteral dilation.  The most common cause in boys is @posterior urethral valves@ or obstructive urogenital membranes at the junction of the bladder and urethra.  Other congenital anomalies at this anatomic level that would also cause bilateral fetal hydronephrosis include urethral strictures, meatal stenosis, and bladder neck obstruction. $#(Choice E)#  Abnormalities at the vesicoureteral junction (eg, congenital anomaly, renal calculi) can cause obstruction but are rare and would lead to ureteral dilation (not seen here) if severe enough to cause hydronephrosis.  Similarly, @vesicoureteral reflux (VUR)@, a common cause of fetal hydronephrosis, is also associated with ureteral dilation/tortuosity. $#Educational objective# Inadequate canalization of the ureter at the ureteropelvic junction (the connection site between the kidney and the ureter) is the most common cause of severe, unilateral fetal hydronephrosis.

title: A 2-week-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for evaluation of his umbilicus.  The parents report that since the umbilical cord stump separated 2 days ago, there has been drainage from the umbilicus that increases when the patient cries.  He is exclusively breastfed and continues to have normal wet diapers and stool output.  The patient was born at term, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated.  Vital signs are normal.  Physical examination of the abdomen shows clear to pale yellow fluid leaking from the umbilical stump site with mucosal tissue at the base of the umbilicus.  Samples are obtained for complete blood count.  Laboratory results are as follows:
title_2: Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's umbilical findings?
answer_3: C. Incomplete closure of anterior abdominal wall
table_3: §^#Neonatal umbilical drainage#∆⨉∆⨉ §^#Diagnosis# ∆^#Anatomy# ∆^#Clinical findings# §^#Umbilical granuloma# ∆ • Excess granulation tissue • No communication with abdomen ∆ • Serous umbilical moisture • Pedunculated mass §^#Patent urachus# ∆ • Connection between umbilicus & bladder ∆ • Persistent leakage of urine §^#Patent omphalomesenteric duct# ∆ • Connection between umbilicus & bowel ∆ • Persistent leakage of stool §^#Omphalitis# ∆ • Infection of umbilical cord stump ∆ • Purulent drainage • Induration/erythema
explanation_2: Umbilical drainage in a neonate may be due to granulation tissue, infection, or congenital anomaly.  In this case, the patient's persistent pale-yellow drainage (consistent with urine) is suggestive of a congenital urachal abnormality. $In utero, the caudal yolk sac normally forms a tubular outpouching called the #allantois#, which extends from the embryologic #bladder to the umbilicus#.  As the bladder descends into the fetal pelvis, it stretches the allantois, which becomes thin and narrow.  Epithelial proliferation obliterates the allantois lumen by 12 weeks gestation, forming a fibrous cord known as the #urachus#. $#Failed obliteration# of the allantois can lead to a #patent urachus#.  This connection between the bladder and the umbilicus results in urinary umbilical drainage that increases with intraabdominal pressure (eg, #crying#, straining, prone positioning).  Partially failed obliteration can result in a range of @defects@, including a urachus that is open to the umbilicus (urachal sinus), open to the bladder (urachal diverticulum), or open only centrally (urachal cyst). $#(Choice A)#  Leukocyte adhesion deficiency is characterized by impaired leukocyte migration due to defective adhesive molecules.  Patients typically have leukocytosis and delayed (>1 month) umbilical cord stump separation, findings not present in this case. $#(Choice B)#  A duplication of the renal collecting system (eg, 2 ureters originating from a single kidney) can result in aberrant insertion of a ureter into structures such as the urethra or epididymis.  The umbilicus is not involved, so umbilical drainage does not occur. $#(Choice C)#  Incomplete closure of the anterior abdominal wall describes @gastroschisis@, in which viscera protrude through an abdominal wall defect adjacent to the umbilicus.  Isolated umbilical drainage is not consistent with this diagnosis. $#(Choice D)#  The omphalomesenteric (or vitelline) duct is a diverticulum of the yolk sac that extends from the embryologic midgut to the umbilicus; it normally involutes in early gestation.  @Persistent patency@ connects the bowel to the umbilicus, and patients may exhibit fecal (not urinary) umbilical discharge. $#Educational objective# The urachus is a remnant of the allantois that extends from the bladder to the umbilicus.  Failed obliteration of the allantois lumen can result in a patent urachus, which presents with urinary drainage from the umbilicus in the neonate.

title: A 25-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks gestation comes to the office with her husband for routine follow-up.  She reports no concerns, and abdominal examination shows normal fundal height.  Anatomy ultrasound of the fetus shows male sex.  The fetus' kidneys appear fused at the lower poles and are located low in the abdomen.  The remainder of the ultrasound is unremarkable.  The couple asks about implications of these findings and the ways they will affect the child after birth.  Which of the following is the best response?
answer_1: A. "Many children with this disorder develop kidney dysfunction that progresses to end-stage renal disease, so we will need to follow up closely for this."
answer_2: B. "Patients with these findings are at an increased risk for forming cerebral aneurysms over their lifetime, so periodic screening is recommended."
answer_3: C. "The majority of patients with this developmental anomaly are asymptomatic, but there is an increased risk for urinary tract infections."
answer_4: D. "These findings are part of a developmental sequence that can lead to impaired lung development with potential respiratory distress at delivery."
answer_5: E. "This genetic condition is associated with varying degrees of liver disease, which warrants periodic imaging of the liver."
right_answer: C. "The majority of patients with this developmental anomaly are asymptomatic, but there is an increased risk for urinary tract infections."
explanation_2: $This patient's prenatal ultrasound reveals a fetus with #fusion of the inferior kidney poles#, a congenital anomaly known as #horseshoe kidney#. $Pathophysiology of horseshoe kidney involves abnormal migration of the right and left metanephric blastema (from which the renal parenchyma is derived), leading to fusion of the developing inferior poles.  The kidneys' physiologic ascent into the abdomen is limited due to the fused parenchyma (isthmus), which is mechanically restricted by the overlying inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) at its origin from the aorta (#low-lying position#). $Most patients with horseshoe kidney and its associated anatomic abnormalities are #asymptomatic#.  However, in some patients, the abnormal position of the kidney and ureters may lead to intermittent ureteropelvic junction obstruction and urinary stasis, which increase the risk for #nephroliths# and #urinary tract infections#. $#(Choices A and D)#  Patients with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) often have decreased renal function in utero, which may lead to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia (@Potter sequence@).  ARPKD also frequently leads to end-stage kidney disease, warranting close monitoring.  However, prenatal ultrasound would reveal large, hyperechogenic kidneys with many tiny cysts in contrast to this patient's fused kidney. $#(Choices B and E)#  Both ARPKD and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) are associated with hepatic manifestations, specifically bile duct dysgenesis and fibrosis in ARPKD and asymptomatic cysts in ADPKD.  Patients with ADPKD are also at risk for cerebral aneurysms due to abnormal gene expression in vascular smooth muscle cells.  Horseshoe kidney is not associated with extrarenal manifestations (eg, liver disease, cerebral aneurysms). $#Educational objective# Horseshoe kidney is a congenital anomaly in which the inferior poles of the developing kidney fuse in utero.  Most patients remain asymptomatic but are at increased risk for recurrent nephroliths and urinary tract infections due to the abnormal orientation and positioning of the kidney.

title: A 1 week-old boy is evaluated in the hospital.  The patient has been admitted due to urosepsis and is receiving antibiotic therapy.  The mother received no prenatal care; the neonate was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery.  Vital signs are normal.  Examination shows lower abdominal distension with normal bowel sounds.  The penis and scrotum appear normal.  Renal ultrasonography and voiding cystourethrography reveal a diffusely thickened bladder wall with bilateral vesicoureteral reflux and hydronephrosis.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
answer_2: B. Failed obliteration of the allantois
answer_3: C. Fusion of the bilateral metanephros
answer_4: D. Persistence of the urogenital membrane
answer_5: E. Stenosis at the ureteropelvic junction
right_answer: D. Persistence of the urogenital membrane
explanation_2: $This patient has a diffusely thickened bladder wall with bilateral vesicoureteral reflux and hydronephrosis, findings consistent with bladder outlet obstruction.  In newborn #boys#, the most common cause is #posterior urethral valves# (PUVs). $In utero, the urethra normally begins as a solid structure that canalizes to form its characteristic tubular structure.  PUVs are likely due to incomplete canalization and are defined by a #persistent urogenital membrane# that obstructs the posterior urethra.  The bladder outlet obstruction, which may be partial or complete, causes increased pressure in the proximal urinary tract, leading to the following: $• #Bladder distension# with an increased contractile force required to overcome the obstruction, resulting in detrusor muscle hypertrophy and bladder #wall thickening# $• Bilateral secondary #vesicoureteral reflux# due to higher pressure in the bladder relative to the ureters and #hydronephrosis# due to retrograde urine flow $Diagnosis is often made via prenatal ultrasound, which may show oligohydramnios if the obstruction is severe.  PUVs diagnosed after birth often present with lower abdominal distension, weak urinary stream (if the obstruction is partial), or urinary tract infection (UTI) due to urinary stasis and reflux. $#(Choice A)#  Primary vesicoureteral reflux is due to a congenitally short intravesical ureter that fails to fully compress during micturition, causing retrograde urine flow.  Ureteral dilation, hydronephrosis, and UTIs may develop, but the bladder is distal to the defect and would not be distended or have a thickened wall. $#(Choice B)#  Failed obliteration of the allantois leads to a patent urachus, or a connection between the bladder and umbilicus.  The risk for UTI is increased, but drainage of urine through the umbilicus is typical and urinary obstruction is not seen. $#(Choices C and E)#  Fusion of the bilateral @metanephros@ (metanephric blastema) causes @horseshoe kidney@.  This condition increases the risk for UTIs, as well as hydronephrosis due to potential ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, but the kidneys would be fused on imaging.  Moreover, the bladder (distal to the defect) would not be distended.  Similarly, isolated UPJ stenosis can cause hydronephrosis but not bladder distension. $#Educational objective# Bladder outlet obstruction leads to increased pressure proximally and findings of bladder distension and wall thickening, secondary vesicoureteral reflux, ureteral dilation, and hydronephrosis.  The most common cause in newborn boys is posterior urethral valves due to a persistent urogenital membrane.

title: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for follow-up care.  The patient recently completed a course of antibiotics for a urinary tract infection caused by Escherichia coli.  He has had 2 febrile urinary tract infections in the past, both of which resolved following antibiotic therapy.  Vital signs are normal.  Examination of the abdomen is unremarkable.  Renal ultrasound examination reveals no signs of hydronephrosis.  Voiding cystourethrogram shows contrast filling the bladder and extending linearly toward the umbilicus.  This patient most likely has a congenital abnormality related to which of the following structures?
explanation_2: $This patient's imaging findings are consistent with a congenital urachal anomaly.  In utero, the caudal yolk sac forms a tubular outpouching called the allantois, which extends from the embryologic bladder to the umbilicus.  As the #bladder descends# into the fetal pelvis, it #stretches the allantois#, which becomes thin and narrow.  Normally, epithelial proliferation obliterates the lumen of the allantois by 12 weeks gestation, forming a #fibrous cord# known as the #urachus#. $Failed or inadequate epithelial proliferation leads to a complete or partial patent urachus: $• Complete patent urachus:  Neonates usually have urinary umbilical drainage on presentation due to a continuous connection from the bladder to the umbilicus. $•  Partial patent urachus#:#  A range of defects may occur depending on the location of the patency, including a urachus that is open only to the umbilicus (urachal sinus), to the bladder (urachal diverticulum), or centrally (urachal cyst). $This patient with a normal abdominal examination most likely has a #urachal diverticulum#, as seen on imaging as a linear extension of urine from the bladder toward the umbilicus.  #Urinary stasis# within the diverticulum is a risk factor for recurrent #urinary tract infection#, as seen in this case. $#(Choice A)#  Similar to the allantois, the @omphalomesenteric@ (or vitelline) duct is a tubular outpouching of the yolk sac that involutes in early gestation.  However, because it connects the yolk sac to the fetal midgut, failed obliteration results in a connection between @umbilicus and bowel@ (not bladder). $#(Choices B and C)#  The umbilical arteries and vein are contained within the umbilical cord, and abnormalities (eg, single umbilical artery) are usually isolated.  These vascular structures are not connected to the bladder lumen. $#(Choice E)#  The ureters are derived from the @mesonephric duct@, and abnormalities may result in ectopic ureteral insertion along the mesonephric system (eg, urethra).  A midline bladder diverticulum directed toward the umbilicus would not be expected. $#(Choice F)#  The urorectal septum divides the cloaca into the distal anorectal and urogenital regions.  Developmental abnormalities would not explain this patient's abnormal urinary flow from the bladder to the umbilicus. $#Educational objective# Congenital anomalies of the urachus result in an abnormal connection between the bladder and the umbilicus.  Full patency results in urinary umbilical leakage, whereas partial patency can result in a range of defects, including a bladder diverticulum (increases the risk of urinary tract infection due to stasis of urine).

title: A 37-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after developing sudden-onset right arm weakness and difficulty speaking.  She has no significant medical history but takes oral contraceptives.  Examination shows decreased right upper extremity strength and expressive aphasia.  Cardiac auscultation is normal.  MRI of the brain reveals acute infarction in the left frontal lobe.  Further evaluation to determine an etiology is performed.  During echocardiogram, agitated normal saline is injected into a peripheral vein and bubbles are seen passing into the left side of the heart.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of the observed finding in this patient?
answer_1: A. Aplasia of the atrial septum secundum
answer_2: B. Failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to develop
answer_3: C. Incomplete closure of the interventricular foramen
answer_4: D. Incomplete fusion of atrial septum primum and secundum
answer_5: E. Persistent channel between aorta and pulmonary artery
right_answer: D. Incomplete fusion of atrial septum primum and secundum
explanation_2: $This young patient had a #cryptogenic stroke#, which is evaluated with echocardiography with a "bubble study" to identify right-to-left intracardiac shunts.  This study is performed by injecting agitated normal saline intravenously and observing for microbubbles in the left heart.  Shunt detection is improved by having the patient release a sustained Valsalva maneuver, which increases right atrial pressure.  Cryptogenic stroke is frequently associated with atrial septal abnormalities such as #patent foramen ovale# (PFO) and atrial septal defect (ASD). $During fetal development, the foramen ovale shunts oxygenated fetal blood across from the right to the left atrium.  After delivery, umbilical cord clamping and decreased pulmonary vascular resistance lower right atrial pressure and raise left atrial pressure.  This pushes the #septum primum# against the #septum secundum#, closing the foramen ovale.  Over time, fibrosis and tissue remodeling fuse the flap closed.  #Incomplete fusion# occurs in approximately 25% of normal adults, resulting in a PFO. $PFO usually remains functionally closed and asymptomatic after birth as left atrial pressure is greater than right atrial pressure.  However, conditions that raise right atrial pressure above left atrial pressure (eg, Valsalva release) produce a transient right-to-left shunt across the PFO.  This is particularly concerning in patients with hypercoagulability (eg, oral contraceptive use) as they are at increased risk for venous thrombosis and #paradoxical brain embolism#.  Chronically elevated right heart pressure (eg, Eisenmenger syndrome) is not necessary for paradoxical embolism. $#(Choice A)#  ASD results from aplasia of the septum primum or septum secundum during development.  Although ASD may lead to paradoxical embolism, it is much less common than PFO and characterized by fixed splitting of S2.  Unrepaired ASDs may lead to heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, or Eisenmenger syndrome. $#(Choice B)#  Incomplete development of the aorticopulmonary septum results in @truncus arteriosus@, which causes cyanosis in newborns and requires early surgical repair. $#(Choice C)#  Incomplete closure of the interventricular foramen results in @ventricular septal defect@ (VSD), which causes a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border.  Large VSDs can cause significant left-to-right shunting, leading to heart failure in infancy; however, VSDs infrequently lead to paradoxical embolism. $#(Choice E)#  The ductus arteriosus functionally closes within 24 hours after delivery.  Persistent @patent ductus arteriosus@ causes a continuous murmur and may eventually result in heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, or Eisenmenger syndrome. $#Educational objective# The foramen ovale is patent in approximately 25% of normal adults.  Although the foramen ovale usually remains functionally closed, transient increases of right atrial pressure above left atrial pressure can produce a right-to-left shunt, leading to paradoxical embolism of venous clots into the arterial circulation.

title: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for evaluation of cyanosis with minimal exertion.  The boy has had occasional episodes of "turning blue" that first began during infancy and are now occurring more frequently.  During the episodes, the boy assumes a squatting position as it makes him "feel better."  The family recently immigrated to the United States; the boy has never had a medical checkup prior to this visit.  Physical examination reveals a prominent right ventricular impulse and a harsh systolic murmur.  Which of the following embryological events is the most likely mechanism that caused this patient's condition?
answer_3: C. Deviation of the infundibular septum
answer_5: E. Linear development of the aorticopulmonary septum
right_answer: C. Deviation of the infundibular septum
explanation_2: $This patient's clinical presentation (#cyanotic spells# that improve with #squatting#, prominent right ventricular impulse, #systolic murmur#) is consistent with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).  Abnormal neural crest cell migration leads to anterior and cephalad deviation of the infundibular septum during embryologic development, resulting in a malaligned VSD and an overriding aorta.  TOF is characterized by 4 distinct anatomic abnormalities: $• Ventricular septal defect (VSD) $• verriding aorta over the right and left ventricles $• Right ventricular outflow tract (RVOT) obstruction $• Right ventricular hypertrophy $Cyanosis occurs due to the presence of right-to-left shunt in patients with severe or worsening #RVOT obstruction#.  The typical harsh, systolic ejection murmur over the mid-to-left upper sternal border is due to the presence of RVOT obstruction (subvalvular, pulmonary valve stenosis or supravalvular narrowing in the main pulmonary artery).  Squatting increases the peripheral systemic vascular resistance (afterload) and decreases the degree of right-to-left shunting across the VSD, thereby improving cyanosis. $#(Choice A)#  In @anomalous pulmonary venous return@, blood from both the pulmonary (oxygenated) and systemic (deoxygenated) venous systems flow into the right atrium, leading to right atrial and ventricular dilation.  Patients also have obligatory right-to-left atrial shunting. $#(Choice B)#  Aortic arch constriction results in @coarctation of the aorta@ and is most commonly located just distal to the left subclavian artery (juxtaductal).  Common manifestations include brachial-femoral pulse delay and blood pressure discrepancy between the upper and lower extremities. $#(Choice D)#  Failed fusion of the superior and inferior endocardial cushions (eg, endocardial cushion defect) results in defects of the atrioventricular septum and valves (mitral and tricuspid valves).  These typically manifest initially as atrial defects and/or VSDs with left-to-right shunting of blood.  Over time, the increased right-sided blood flow leads to pulmonary hypertension with reversal of blood flow through the shunt and development of cyanosis (@Eisenmenger syndrome@).  This patient has had cyanotic symptoms since birth that would not be expected with an isolated endocardial cushion defect. $#(Choice E)#  @Transposition of the great arteries@ results from linear, rather than spiral, development of the aorticopulmonary septum in utero. $#Educational objective# Tetralogy of Fallot results from anterior and cephalad deviation of the infundibular septum during embryologic development, resulting in a malaligned ventricular septal defect (VSD) with an overriding aorta.  As a result, the patient has right ventricular outflow obstruction (resulting in a systolic murmur) and squats to increase the peripheral systemic vascular resistance (afterload) and decrease right-to-left shunting across the VSD.

title: A 1-hour-old girl is evaluated in the delivery room.  The infant was born at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery following an uncomplicated pregnancy.  The mother is gravida 2 para 2 and has no significant medical history.  Apgar scores were 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  The patient has been skin-to-skin with her mother and breastfed once without difficulty.  Physical examination shows a pink, alert infant.  Cardiac auscultation reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs, and femoral pulses are normal.  Which of the following hemodynamic changes most likely occurred during the fetal-to-neonatal transition at birth?
comparison_items: §∆Systemic vascular resistance ∆Pulmonary vascular resistance ∆Left ventricular contribution to systemic blood flow
explanation_2: $#Fetal circulation# is characterized by: $• #High pulmonary vascular resistance# (PVR):  In utero, the lungs are filled with amniotic fluid, which causes diffuse vasoconstriction of the pulmonary capillary beds (hypoxic vasoconstriction). $• #Low systemic vascular resistance# (SVR):  The fetal systemic circulation is connected in parallel to the low-resistance placental vascular bed via the umbilical arteries (which deliver deoxygenated blood to the placenta) and umbilical vein (which delivers oxygenated blood to the fetus). $In the fetus, PVR is greater than SVR; the foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus allow blood to be shunted away from the high resistance pulmonary circulation into the low resistance systemic circulation (ie, right-to-left shunting), bypassing the lungs.  Because the ductus arteriosus is a high-caliber shunt, the #right ventricle# contributes approximately #60 percent# of the fetal systemic blood flow (and the left ventricle contributes the remainder). $At birth, fetal circulation transitions to #neonatal circulation#, which is characterized by: $• #Decreased PVR#:  Pulmonary expansion and aeration lead to diffuse pulmonary vasodilation. $• #Increased SVR#:  Umbilical cord clamping abruptly removes the low-resistance placenta from neonatal circulation. $Because SVR is now greater than PVR, shunting through the ductus arteriosus reverses to left-to-right shunting (triggering eventual closure of the ductus).  With the cessation of right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus at birth, #only the left ventricle# contributes to systemic blood flow. $#Educational objective# Before birth, high pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) and low systemic vascular resistance (SVR) facilitate right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus, and both ventricles contribute to fetal systemic blood flow.  At birth, decreased PVR (due to oxygenation and ventilation of the lungs) and increased SVR (due to umbilical cord clamping) reverse shunting through the ductus arteriosus (ie, left-to-right shunting), and only the left ventricle contributes to systemic blood flow.

title: A 2-day-old boy is being evaluated in the nursery for irritability.  He was born to a 22-year-old primigravida who received limited prenatal care.  Delivery was uncomplicated, and Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F), blood pressure is 70/30 mm Hg, pulse is 148/min, and respirations are 68/min.  On physical examination, the patient is cyanotic and irritable.  Auscultation reveals a continuous, machinery-like murmur appreciated between the scapulae.  Serum lactate level is elevated.  Echocardiogram shows the origin of the aorta lying anterior and to the right of the pulmonary artery.  Failure of which of the following processes during embryonic development is most likely responsible for this patient's findings on imaging?
explanation_2: $This newborn's echocardiogram is indicative of #transposition of the great arteries# (TGA), a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by @abnormal origination@ of the aorta/pulmonary artery.  In early gestation, there is a single outflow tract from the rudimentary heart that is subsequently divided into the aorta and pulmonary artery by the #aorticopulmonary septum#.  This septum normally spirals during outflow tract division to create an anteriorly located pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle and a posteriorly located aorta arising from the left ventricle. $TGA occurs due to #failed spiraling# of the aorticopulmonary septum, resulting in an #anterior aorta# that originates from the right ventricle and a #posterior pulmonary artery# that originates from the left ventricle.  @Parallel@ pulmonary and systemic circuits are created, and #deoxygenated blood# is delivered from the right ventricle to the #systemic circulation# via the aorta. $Neonates with TGA often have cyanosis, tachypnea, and tachycardia immediately after birth; however, some may have normal examination findings initially due to shunting of oxygenated blood to the systemic circulation via the @ductus arteriosus@, with cyanosis developing after 24-48 hours as the ductus begins to close.  Other mixing lesions, such as a large ventricular septal defect, can also mask the development of clinically-apparent cyanosis.  In this patient, elevated lactate is caused by a high degree of anaerobic metabolism due to poor oxygen delivery to the tissues. $#(Choices A and C)#  Failed fusion of the septum primum with the endocardial cushions leads to a primum-type atrial septal defect @(ASD)@, whereas failed proliferation of the septum secundum leads to a secundum-type ASD.  An ASD would not cause neonatal cyanosis. $#(Choice B)#  Failed obliteration of the ductus arteriosus results in a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which by itself would not explain neonatal cyanosis.  PDA in a patient with TGA tends to delay the development of cyanosis. $#(Choice D)#  Failed conotruncal septation results in persistent @truncus arteriosus@.  Although affected patients typically develop neonatal cyanosis, an echocardiogram would reveal a single arterial trunk.  This patient's distinct aorta and pulmonary artery indicate conotruncal septation has occurred. $#Educational objective# Transposition of the great arteries is a cyanotic congenital heart condition resulting from failed spiraling of the aorticopulmonary septum during embryonic development.  The aorta aberrantly originates from the right ventricle, lies anterior to the pulmonary artery, and delivers deoxygenated blood to the systemic circulation.

title: Researchers conduct a study in an animal fetus with circulation similar to that of humans.  The fetus is delivered close to term by cesarean delivery.  Prior to placental separation and the initiation of pulmonary respiration, blood samples are simultaneously collected from several different fetal blood vessels.  The blood oxygen saturations measured from each of the samples are 71%, 64%, 62%, 55%, and 43%.  The sample with the greatest oxygen saturation was most likely obtained from which of the following blood vessels?
explanation_2: $Fetal circulation differs considerably from adult circulation in that #oxygen# is supplied to the fetus by the mother's #placenta#, no gas exchange occurs in the fetal lungs, and the majority of blood is directed away from the lungs via right-to-left shunting (eg, foramen ovale, ductus arteriosus). $Oxygenated blood from the placenta is delivered to the fetus via the #umbilical vein#.  Upon entering the fetal abdomen, a portion of this oxygen-rich blood is directed to the portal vein to supply the liver, while the majority is shunted through the #ductus venosus# to the #inferior vena cava# (IVC).  In the IVC, oxygen-rich blood from the ductus venosus runs alongside a stream of deoxygenated blood returning from the lower body. $As blood from the IVC enters the right atrium, a #preferential streaming# effect allows the majority of the oxygenated blood to pass directly through the #foramen ovale# into the left atrium.  The oxygen-rich blood delivered to the left atrium proceeds to the left ventricle and out the aorta, where it is supplied to the brain, myocardium (via the coronary arteries), and upper extremities. $Meanwhile, deoxygenated blood from the IVC and superior vena cava fills the right atrium and proceeds to the right ventricle.  #High pulmonary vascular resistance# causes most of the blood ejected into the pulmonary trunk to be shunted away from the lungs, with 90% of the deoxygenated blood being shunted through the #ductus arteriosus# into the aorta #(choices B and D)#.  This deoxygenated blood mixes with the oxygen-rich blood in the aorta, sending moderately oxygenated blood down the descending aorta to supply the intestines, kidneys, and lower body. $#(Choice A)#  Oxygen saturation in the descending aorta is significantly lower than in the ductus venosus because the oxygenated blood in the descending aorta is mixed with deoxygenated blood from both the lower and the upper body. $#(Choice E)#  The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood returning from the brain and upper extremities. $#(Choice F)#  The umbilical arteries branch off the internal iliac arteries to return moderately oxygenated blood to the placenta, where carbon dioxide and other wastes are unloaded and oxygen is again collected. $#Educational objective# The most highly oxygenated blood in the fetus is carried by the umbilical vein, which empties directly into the inferior vena cava via the ductus venosus.

title: A 64-year-old man loses consciousness near the entrance to an emergency room.  A physician rushes to the patient and palpates a strong pulse along the inner side of the left sternocleidomastoid muscle.  The vessel palpated by the doctor is a derivative of which of the following aortic arches?
table_3: §^#Arches & associated cranial nerves#∆⨉∆⨉ §^#Pharyngeal and aortic arch# ∆^#Cranial nerve# ∆^#Key aortic arch derivatives# §^1 ∆^Trigeminal (CN V) ∆^Maxillary artery (portion) §^2 ∆^Facial (CN VII) ∆^Stapedial artery (regresses) §^3 ∆^Glossopharyngeal (CN IX) ∆^Common carotid artery, proximal internal carotid artery §^4 ∆^Superior laryngeal branch of vagus (CN X) ∆^True aortic arch, subclavian arteries §^5 ∆^Obliterated ∆^Obliterated §^6 ∆^Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus (CN X) ∆^Pulmonary arteries, ductus arteriosus
explanation_2: $During embryonic development, the head, neck, and upper thorax region develop from a set of arches known as #pharyngeal arches#.  Each arch is associated with a @cranial nerve@ and an aortic arch derivative.  The vessel palpated in this patient is the #common carotid artery#, which (along with the proximal portion of the internal carotid artery) is derived from the #third aortic arch# (ie, third pharyngeal arch).  The third pharyngeal arch also gives rise to the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), parts of the hyoid bone, and the stylopharyngeus muscle. $#(Choice A)#  The first pharyngeal arch is associated with the trigeminal nerve (CN V).  This pharyngeal arch gives rise to the tensor tympani, muscles of mastication, maxilla, and inner ear bones (eg, incus, malleus).  The associated first aortic arch regresses almost completely, although it does give rise to a portion of the maxillary artery. $#(Choice B)#  The second pharyngeal arch is associated with the facial nerve (CN VII).  This pharyngeal arch gives rise to the muscles of facial expression as well as some ear and hyoid structures.  The stapedial artery is a derivative of the associated second aortic arch, but this vessel typically regresses. $#(Choice D)#  The fourth pharyngeal arch is associated with the superior laryngeal branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).  This pharyngeal arch gives rise to many of the muscles of the pharynx and soft palate as well as a few of the laryngeal muscles.  The associated fourth aortic arch gives rise to part of the true aortic arch and subclavian arteries. $#(Choice E)#  The sixth pharyngeal arch is associated with the recurrent laryngeal branches of CN X.  This pharyngeal arch gives rise to most of the muscles of the larynx, and the associated aortic arch gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus. $#Educational objective# The common carotid artery and the proximal portion of the internal carotid artery are derived from the third aortic arch.  The third aortic arch is associated with the third pharyngeal arch, which gives rise to the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), parts of the hyoid bone, and the stylopharyngeus muscle.

title: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a painful mass in the neck.  The parents noticed a small area of nontender swelling in the neck a month ago.  Over the last few days, it has enlarged and become painful, and the patient has a fever.  Examination shows a mobile, tender, fluctuant, and warm mass approximately 2 cm in diameter that is located at the right mandibular angle.  There is purulent drainage from the skin surface just anterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle.
